Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Broadband Seismic Experiment to Image the Lithosphere Beneath the Gamburtsev Mountains and Surrounding Areas, East Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
This award supports a seismological study of the Gamburtsev Subglacial Mountains (GSM), a Texas-sized mountain range buried beneath the ice sheets of East Antarctica. The project will perform a passive seismic experiment deploying twenty-three seismic stations over the GSM to characterize the structure of the crust and upper mantle, and determine the processes driving uplift. The outcomes will also offer constraints on the terrestrial heat flux, a key variable in modeling ice sheet formation and behavior. Virtually unexplored, the GSM represents the largest unstudied area of crustal uplift on earth. As well, the region is the starting point for growth of the Antarctic ice sheets.
Because of these outstanding questions, the GSM has been identified by the international Antarctic science community as a research focus for the International Polar Year (2007-2009). In addition to this seismic experiment, NSF is also supporting an aerogeophysical survey of the GSM under award number 0632292. Major international partners in the project include Germany, China, Australia, and the United Kingdom. For more information see IPY Project #67 at IPY.org. In terms of broader impacts, this project also supports postdoctoral and graduate student research, and various forms of outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved deploying 26 seismic stations across the Gamburtsev Subglacial Mountains (GSM) in East Antarctica to investigate the geological age and significance of this remote region.   The stations were successfully deployed and operated year-around with a high level (85-90%) of data return.    Analysis of the data shows that the  GSM are underlain by geologically old cratonic lithosphere. This is indicated by the uniformly high shear velocities in the upper mantle, and comparison to other cratonic areas around the world.   This  rules out models for the formation of the GSM that propose Mesozoic or Cenozoic volcanism or tectonism. The high elevation of the mountains is supported by anomalously thick continental crust (55 km), suggesting the mountains are a long-lived high region formed by tectonic activity prior to the Mesozoic (250 million years ago).   This shows that the East Antarctic highlands have been topographically elevated throughout recent geological history and have formed a locus for the development and expansion of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet.  

This project aided in the development and testing of a new generation of polar seismograph equipment by technicians from IRIS/PASSCAL.   Some of this technology is readily transferable to other areas of polar field data collection.   Three Washington University graduate students were also trained in field seismology and polar field operations, and outreach talks were given in several venues.
